section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: Maajh, Fifth Mehl, Chau-Padas, First House:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਮੇਰਾ ਮਨੁ ਲੋਚੈ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਸਨ ਤਾਈ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: My mind longs for the Blessed Vision of the Guru's Darshan.

transliteration.text: mērā man lōchai gur darasan tāī .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: It cries out like the thirsty song-bird.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

text: ਤ੍ਰਿਖਾ ਨ ਉਤਰੈ ਸਾਂਤਿ ਨ ਆਵੈ ਬਿਨੁ ਦਰਸਨ ਸੰਤ ਪਿਆਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: My thirst is not quenched, and I can find no peace, without the Blessed Vision of the Beloved Saint. ||1||

transliteration.text: trikhā n utarai sānht n āvai bin darasan sant piārē jīu .1.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਹਉ ਘੋਲੀ ਜੀਉ ਘੋਲਿ ਘੁਮਾਈ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਸਨ ਸੰਤ ਪਿਆਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, my soul is a sacrifice, to the Blessed Vision of the Beloved Saint Guru. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī jīu ghōl ghumāī gur darasan sant piārē jīu .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. text: ਤੇਰਾ ਮੁਖੁ ਸੁਹਾਵਾ ਜੀਉ ਸਹਜ ਧੁਨਿ ਬਾਣੀ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: Your Face is so Beautiful, and the Sound of Your Words imparts intuitive wisdom.

transliteration.text: tērā mukh suhāvā jīu sahaj dhun bānī .

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: It is so long since this rainbird has had even a glimpse of water.

text: ਧੰਨੁ ਸੁ ਦੇਸੁ ਜਹਾ ਤੂੰ ਵਸਿਆ ਮੇਰੇ ਸਜਣ ਮੀਤ ਮੁਰਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: Blessed is that land where You dwell, O my Friend and Intimate Divine Guru. ||2||

transliteration.text: dhann s dēs jahā tūn vasiā mērē sajan mīt murārē jīu .2.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, I am forever a sacrifice, to my Friend and Intimate Divine Guru. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī hau ghōl ghumāī gur sajan mīt murārē jīu .1. rahāu .

text: ਇਕ ਘੜੀ ਨ ਮਿਲਤੇ ਤਾ ਕਲਿਜੁਗੁ ਹੋਤਾ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: When I could not be with You for just one moment, the Dark Age of Kali Yuga dawned for me.

transliteration.text: ik gharī n milatē tā kalijug hōtā .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਹੁਣਿ ਕਦਿ ਮਿਲੀਐ ਪ੍ਰਿਅ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਗਵੰਤਾ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: When will I meet You, O my Beloved Lord?

transliteration.text: hun kad milīai pri tudh bhagavantā .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਮੋਹਿ ਰੈਣਿ ਨ ਵਿਹਾਵੈ ਨੀਦ ਨ ਆਵੈ ਬਿਨੁ ਦੇਖੇ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਬਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I cannot endure the night, and sleep does not come, without the Sight of the Beloved Guru's Court. ||3||

transliteration.text: mōh rain n vihāvai nīd n āvai bin dēkhē gur darabārē jīu .3.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਹਉ ਘੋਲੀ ਜੀਉ ਘੋਲਿ ਘੁਮਾਈ ਤਿਸੁ ਸਚੇ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਬਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, my soul is a sacrifice, to that True Court of the Beloved Guru. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī jīu ghōl ghumāī tis sachē gur darabārē jīu .1. rahāu .

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: By good fortune, I have met the Saint Guru.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I have found the Immortal Lord within the home of my own self.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਸੇਵ ਕਰੀ ਪਲੁ ਚਸਾ ਨ ਵਿਛੁੜਾ ਜਨ ਨਾਨਕ ਦਾਸ ਤੁਮਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I will now serve You forever, and I shall never be separated from You, even for an instant. Servant Nanak is Your slave, O Beloved Master. ||4||

transliteration.text: sēv karī pal chasā n vishurā jan nānak dās tumārē jīu .4.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, my soul is a sacrifice; servant Nanak is Your slave, Lord. ||Pause||1||8||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī jīu ghōl ghumāī jan nānak dās tumārē jīu . rahāu .1.8.
